titleStmt.title: The most pleasant and delightful historie of Curan, a prince of Danske, and the fayre Princesse Argentile, daughter and heyre to Adelbright, sometime King of Northumberland Shewing his first loue vnto her, his succeslesse suite, and the low deiections he vnderwent for her sake. His second loue to the same lady vnknowne, taking her for a poore countrie damsell. She (by reason of the vnkindnesse of King Edell her vnckle and gardian) hauing forsooke the court, and vndertooke the profession of a neatheardes mayde. His constant loue (after her long continued vnkindnes) rewarded with her wished consent, their happie nuptials, and mutuall reioycings, his valour and victorious warre with King Edell: and lastly, his peacefull installment in the kingly throne. Enterlacte with many pritty and pithie prayses of beauty, and other amorous discourses, pleasing, smooth and delightfull. By William Webster.
titleStmt.author: Webster, William, treatise writer.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.head: TO THE WORSHIPFVL Mr. THOMAS EVErard of Heather, in the Countie of Leyce≈øter, E≈øq all increa≈øe of ≈øuch Ble≈ø≈øings as make this life happie and comfortable, and of ≈øuch Graces, as may make the next Ble≈ø≈øed and Glorious.
div.p:
SYR, purpo≈øing to impo≈øe ≈øome taske on my wandring thoughts ≈øo to reuer≈øe their ≈øomewhat vncomfortable ≈øtrayings, my ra≈øher election ≈øuddainly ≈øingled out this ≈øubiect, which though ≈øuting too neerely with my braine in barrennes, the product is this Pamphlet, which peru≈øed by ≈øome friends of iudgement, was pronounced worthy the Pre≈ø≈øe. Wherevnto I the rather referr'd it, that dedicating the ≈øame vnto you, I might (at lea≈øt) manife≈øt my remembrance of that loue, kindne≈ø≈øe, and courte≈øie, which (while my re≈øidence was in loued Leyce≈øter-≈øhire,) made mee ≈øo much affect that Familiaritie, which you then plea≈øed to affoord me, in regard wherof my loue leades me to pre≈øent this to your patronage, and your affection to Poe≈øie, makes mee pre≈øume of your acceptance: the grace you giue a Ver≈øe in reading it, makes it plea≈øing, if it be
but pa≈ø≈øable, therefore I doubt not your liking. And if this (which is not vnlike) gaine your approbation, I ≈øhall not pa≈ø≈øe for the Cen≈øures of ≈øuch as are more apt to finde fault, then able to finde a faulte. Had I but the name of a Poet, and opinion on my ≈øide, I ≈øhould relye therevpon as Cae≈øar on his Fortune, yet doth not my ob≈øcuritie di≈øcourage mee, but rather the contrarie, for Fame is rather to be ventred for then ventred.

An in≈øtigation to the writing hereof, was the commendation which I heard a Iudicious diuine giue of a yong Student in diuinity, for his dexteritie in Engli≈øh Poe≈øie, who affirming it to be an ornament to any profe≈ø≈øion, I was thereby induced to reduce that affection I bore it, to practi≈øe. And in publi≈øhing the ≈øame I haue imitated Apelles, who hauing drawne a picture plea≈øing to him≈øelfe, hang'd it in open viewe, that he might heare the verdite of others. Nor is it vnlike but I al≈øo ≈øhall haue a ≈øhoo-maker Cen≈øuring the Legge, when his skill extends but to the latcher. So (referring it to your fauourable ≈øuruey, and kinde acceptance) I humbly de≈øire Almightie God to Crowne you, and your adopted-≈øelfe, with his be≈øt ble≈ø≈øings in this life, and with Immortall glory in the next.

closer.signed: Your Wor≈øhips Kin≈øman, to be commanded, in a more acceptable ≈øeruice. WILLIAM WEBSTER.

div.head: To M. Iohn Euerard Senior, Gentleman.

lg.l: YOu ≈øole ≈øuruiuer, yet the elde≈øt brother
Of fower, and of a Si≈øter, my late Mother;
Who, (next before you) tendred Natures debt,
Which yet you owe, and long may owe it yet.
What i≈øt? your Courage keepes you ≈øtill aliue,
To be the fir≈øt, and yet the la≈øt of fiue.
Sure t'is your valour; Deaths approach thus ≈øtayes,
Which was admir'd in your more youthfull dayes.
If in a mortals lookes may boldne≈ø≈øe lye
Which may the pale Hor≈øe-ryder terrifie,
Then (it may be) he ≈øhunnes becau≈øe he feares you,
And vntill Age ≈øubdue you, thus forbeares you.
Your oft-tryde valour, valour oft did trye,
Which now intombed in your Age doth lye.
And if your grauitie thinke not vn≈øit,
Let the≈øe lines be the Epitah for it,
As for your Vertues, they yet liue, and they
Shall be remembred in your Epitah.
READER, Let not thy gentle eye di≈ødaine
To walke along my lines ≈øo ≈ømooth ≈øo plaine;
Delightfull walkes they happily may proue,
So they may catch thy liking, I thy loue;
This volume, (though not large) at large di≈øcouers
The fortunes of a payre of princely Louers,
Prince Curan and the Prince≈ø≈øe Argentile.
He ≈øtranger, ≈øhe a natiue of our I≈øle.
He one for lineaments, and gifts of mind:
Such as the like to him was hard to find:
And ≈øure, if to be amorous be no blot
To vertue, then his vertues had no ≈øpot,
And ≈øhee, a dame who≈øe beauty ≈øo excell'd,
That in tho≈øe dayes ≈øhee was not paralell'd,
And, if ≈øhe were not coy more then ≈øhee ≈øhould,
No imputation could on her take hold,
How loue, from Lordline≈ø≈øe doth him debace,
And makes him to ≈øupply a pea≈øants place:
And how his loue to ≈øhunne, th'a≈ø≈øaults of loue,
From Court to Cottage doth her ≈øelfe remoue.
The≈øe things are here di≈øcour≈øt, and here is ≈øhowne
How he the ≈øecond time loues her vnknowne,
How long he wooes her, how at la≈øt he ≈øped,
Though not till then, when all his hopes were dead,
Then how he conquered him in bloudie fight
That wrongfully v≈øurpt his Ladyes right,
(Then which) his former taske was farre more hard,
This la≈øt was ea≈øie with the fir≈øt compar'd,
T'was more to him his Ladyes loue to gaine
Then to giue end vnto a tyrants raigne:
To conquer her affections was a thing
More hard to him then to vncrowne a King,
Nay, all the weapons in the≈øe wars imployde,
Again≈øt the Prince, not him ≈øo much annoy'd,
As did his Ladies angry frownes, for tho≈øe
Could daunt him more then all his armed foes:
How he was ray≈ø'd vnto a Kingly throne,
That low deiections long had vndergone,
Concludes this booke, which read vnto the end,
Perhaps to thee, it may it ≈øelfe commend:
Thus (of thy wi≈øhes) wi≈øhing thee po≈ø≈øe≈øt,
(For kind acceptance onely.) Thine I re≈øt.

div.head: TO THE FAIRE READER, OF THE FAYRER SEX.

lg.l: YOu louely DAME, who≈øe beautie is as much
As was this louely Dames, faire Argentile:
For in the world, where ≈øhould wee looke for ≈øuch,
If not where ≈øhee was bred, in this faire Ile.
For breeeding ≈øuch, our Clime; then other Climes
More fertile is, our times, then former times.
You are the very ≈øame, yea, you are ≈øhee,
Who≈øe Beautie in this Booke is ≈øo commended:
And though your Name not Argentile it be,
Yet know your ≈øelfe is ≈øhee that's here intended.
The≈øe lines were writ for you, of them make v≈øe,
And Beauties prai≈øes to your ≈øelfe reduce.
You liuing, louely Dame, t'was for your ≈øake,
That this in≈øuing taske I vndertooke:
Not hers, ≈øhee' ‚Ä¢ dead, ≈øhee'l no requitall make,
But at your hands (at lea≈øt) for thankes I looke.
To grace what graceth you, I here haue ≈øought,
Then deigne to grace me with a gracious thought.
You are faire (as was ≈øhee) but be not tho,
Coy (as was ≈øhee) O varry you in this:
I would not for the world you ≈øhould be ≈øo,
For then as good that you the world did mi≈ø≈øe.
Vnle≈ø≈øe your kindne≈ø≈øe ≈øhould (as hers) at la≈øt,
Make large amends, for your vnkindne≈ø≈øe pa≈øt.
Had I pray≈ø'd Bountie(≈øo)perhaps my paine,
Might haue bene recompenced with reward:
Then let me not prai≈øe Beauty (thus) in vaine,
Afford me in requitall ≈øome regard.
You I haue ≈øought to plea≈øe, and I from you,
Due thankes, and due re≈øpect, expect: Adue.

div.head: THE PLEASANT AND delightfull Storie of Prince Curan, and the Prince≈ø≈øe Argentile.

lg.l: THen when our Engli≈øh Ile (which now in one
Vnited is, the more our happine≈ø≈øe)
Vnder diuided Soueraignety did grone,
Ichouah ≈øhield it from the like di≈øtre≈ø≈øe;
Seuen Kings then raigned in this land, but now
All hearts, all knees, loue one, to one doe bow.
(Then Diria) called now Northumberland,
Was of the fore≈øaid ≈øeuen ≈ømall Kingdomes one,
Nor was that Scepter ≈øway'd by one mans hand,
Diui≈øion had the Clime ≈øo ouergone,
Two, each a ≈øemi-king raign'd ioyntly there
In friendly peace, for they neere Kin≈ømen were.
Edell and Adelbright the Kings were cal'd,
For each of them the kingly title beares,
And each is in the kingly throne in≈øtal'd,
Thing ≈øeldome ≈øeene) well, after diuers yeares,
King Adelbright decea≈øt, and left his Heire
To Edell's ward, young Argentile the fayre.
Yet ere he dyes, to Edell thus he ≈øpake,
Edell, quoth he, my death approacheth neere,
My Kingly right to thee I doe betake,
During the nonage of my daughter deare,
But after it ≈øhall be to her re≈øign'd,
So thou thy ≈øelfe to mee by oath ≈øhalt binde.
His oath for this, his promi≈øe tooke be≈øide,
To deale with her, as if his childe ≈øhee were.
The good King Adelbright ≈øoone after dyde,
For whom young Argentile ≈øhed many a teare:
And time increa≈øt her griefe, for afterwards
Edell nor oath, nor hone≈øty regardes.
The Scepter whole now his, hee'l not deuide,
V≈øurping that, that is the Ladies right;
(Though he from that by oath him≈øelfe had tide;)
For in ≈øole ≈øoueraignty he found delight,
By her he knowes he cannot be con≈øtrain'd,
Therefore hee'l not forgoe what he hath gain'd.
Meane while the Lady in de≈øpight of woes,
Which ≈øtill too much afflict her tender heart,
The fayre≈øt vnderneath the skie ≈øhe growes,
Beauty is hers in full, and not in part;
Be≈øides, ≈øhee's mode≈øt, ≈øober, gentle, cha≈øt,
Her beautie the≈øe, and the≈øe her beauty grac't.
But when her beauty grew yet more mature,
All beauties then in her ≈øeem'd to combine,
Her beautie other beauties did ob≈øcure,
As ≈øtarres eclip≈øed are by Luna's ≈øhine.
In all the land was none ≈øo fayre as ≈øhee,
In all the world a fayrer could not be.
Her beautie ≈øeemeth to be be „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øoule,
It doth in excellence ≈øo much exceede,
Her eye ≈øo ≈øwayes, ≈øo rules, doth ≈øo controule,
And hend the hearts of men, as wind the reede,
All like, all pray≈øe, and many loue, but few
(Di≈øpayring of their worth) for loue dare ≈øue.
The riche≈øt beauties (to adorne this Dame)
In her fayre trea≈øurie, fetcht Nature thence,
Which neere vnto diuine perfection came,
They did ≈øo much exceed in excellence.
Shee's beauties ≈øunne, who≈øe beames been fame and prai≈øe
Go through & through the world like Phabus raies.
That beauty was but ≈øuch (if it was ≈øuch)
That carried Troy to Greece, and Greece to Troy;
Shee's more then fayre, and therefore more then much
Will be his ioy that once ≈øhall her enioy.
But he mu≈øt ≈øayle, ere he ≈øuch Hauen gaine,
Clo≈øe by the margent of Caribdis maine.
Her eye loues Arbor is where beauties meete,
Her cheeke loues garden is where beauties grow:
Loue walketh there, for there the ayre is ≈øweet:
Which alwayes when ≈øhe breathes doth gently blow.
Her blu≈øhing lip, her breath, for ≈øhew, for ≈ømell,
The Ro≈øe exceedes, the Violet doth excell.
As many as behold her, doe admire her,
In beautie, ≈øhee all beauties doth out-≈øtrip,
All thoughts commend her, and all hearts de≈øire her:
Yea, Nature vvonders at her workman≈øhippe,
Admiring her owne skill, and cunning great,
In framing ≈øuch a beautie, ≈øo compleat.
Nature, another cannot make more fayre,
Though to that purpo≈øe all her power were ben't,
No, though ≈øhee would from fire, earth, water, ayre,
Extract the quinte≈ø≈øence to that ineene.
For in this Dame there no ingredient lackt,
That ≈øhould make beautie perfect and exact.
Had Iupiter the earth frequented then,
When her bright beauty grac't the ≈øunne-≈øhine day,
Or had this Beauties Patragon liu'd when
He in the world did wanton, ≈øport and play.
O what would he haue done, what not haue done?
What ≈øhapes would hee haue tooke her loue t'haue wonne?
Surely he would haue thought her loue a fea≈øt
More plea≈øing then th'imbracement of his queene;
And Iuno's iealou≈øie had ≈øure increa≈øt,
If ≈øhe this peerele≈ø≈øe prince≈ø≈øe ≈øhould haue ≈øeene.
For, that his heart was tractable ≈øhe knew,
For ≈øuch attractiue beautie to ≈øubdue.
In this regard ≈øhe might haue feared much,
Had this Dames beauty beene to Ioue apparrant:
But the cha≈øt heart of this cha≈øt Dame is ≈øuch,
That Inno might haue tooke it for her warrant.
Diana's warrant could not be more ≈øtrong
Touching her ≈øelfe, concerning ≈øuch a wrong.
When Mars in Venus armes was entertain'd,
Her bre≈øts di≈øclo≈ø'd, her bo≈øome open layde,
Her deare imbracements had not him re≈øtrain'd,
Nor would he in that Circle fayre haue ≈øtayde.
Had ≈øuch a one as Argentile pa≈øt by,
Her face pre≈øented to the War-god's tye.
Her necke, barbre≈øts, her hand „Äà‚óä„Äâ legge, „Äà‚óä„Äâ ,
All core≈øpond the beauty of „Äà‚óä„Äâ face.
Who would not (might he be prefer'd vntoot)
With willingne≈ø≈øe her wand like wa≈øt imbeace,
And if her „Äà‚óä„Äâ ca≈øt in a circle were,
Who would not wi≈øh him≈øelfe the Center there.
Had Hereules falne into ≈øuch fayre armes,
So ≈øtrong they are (≈øtrength in their fairene≈ø≈øe lyes)
That though the ≈øounding trumpets ≈øhrill alarm's
Had cal'd him thence to ≈øome great enterpri≈øe,
They would haue held him ≈øtill, ≈øtill him detain'd;
Ah, who could ≈øtruggle, that were ≈øo inchain'd.
Fayrer was ≈øhe then I haue ≈øayde ≈øhe was,
Nor haue I halfe her beauties worth di≈øclo≈ø'd,
Nor can I door, it did ≈øo much ≈øurpa≈ø≈øe.
But what is vnexpre≈øt, let be ≈øuppo≈ø'd,
And as her beauty, ≈øo her vertues ≈øhinde;
Men ioy'd, heauen ioy'd, to ≈øee her face, her mind.
But I mu≈øt leaue her beauty ≈øo excelling,
For I would ha≈øt, and therefore ≈øhun delayes:
Yet on this theame is ≈øuch delightfull dwelling,
That I am loath to leaue her beauties pray≈øe;
How ≈øhe was lou'd, (Loue waites on beauty ≈øo
As ≈øhadow doth on ≈øub≈øtance) now ile ≈øhow.
A ≈øweet young Prince of Danske (by fame cal'd forth)
Curan he hight; this Prince to England came
To ≈øee the Dame, who≈øe matchle≈ø≈øe beauties worth,
Was brought to him vpon the wings of Fame:
He ≈øees the Dame, her beautie ≈øeeth he,
And pray≈øeth in his thoughts what he doth ≈øee.
And though report had ≈øo extol'd her name,
And prai≈ø'd her for ≈øweet loueline≈ø≈øe ≈øo much,
He findes that Fame but li≈øpt, and was to blame,
For (≈øeeing her) hee ≈øee's her beautie ≈øuch,
As ≈øores aboue her pray≈øe, yea, I may ≈øay,
Aboue ≈øuperlatiue, if beautie may.
And now in him his progre≈ø≈øe loue beganne,
From looking, liking, loue from liking grew,
The ≈øpacious world could not produce a man,
That loued with a loue ≈øo firme, ≈øo true,
But for her loue much woe he vnderwent,
Ere ≈øhee (vnkind) would to his ≈øute con≈øent.
This ≈øweet young louely Prince is ≈øuch another,
As was Adonis in his greate≈øt pride:
This Dame is Venus, (that was Capid's mother,
That by Adonis was of loue denide:)
